etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in Edmund Spenser (?1552–1599), poet and administrator in Ireland. Probably an alteration of hippotame, variant of hippopotamus, after either ancient Greek ἱππόδαμος hippodame or the name of Hippodamia (ancient Greek Ἱπποδάμεια), wife of Pelops; with the sense compare earlier hippopotamus

definitions: Probably: a mythical creature with the head, neck, shoulders, and forelegs of a horse and a body ending in the tail of a fish or dolphin.

notes.text: Only in or with reference to Spenser's Faerie Queene. In some later editions glossed simply as hippopotamus.
